text: (spoon clanging)
(egg cracking)
(pan sizzling)
- Hello, and welcome to SORTEDfood.

Now, today is going to
be a very special episode

cause we've teamed up
with Taste France magazine

by the French Ministry
of Agriculture and Food
in challenging our three normal home cooks
to conjure up a French three course meal
using French produce to be judged

as if the ante wasn't there
already by a French chef.
Welcome chef Franck.
- Thank you for inviting me, loving it.

- We've had a bit of research
already a few weeks ago.

Jamie and I had the pleasure
of tasting French cuisine
in Paris on an unexpected journey.

So they're going to
put that into practise.
- [Jamie] Yeah, we ate and drank a lot
and we got to speak to a lot of experts
who know a lot about French produce.

- And therefore, the question
is, did you learn it?
Did you remember it?

And have you shared
that with Mike and Barry
to help you in this challenge?
- Franck, do the honours...
- Two hours is not a lot of time guys.
So stop, stop "faffing" about.
(everyone laughing)
So it's 3, 2, 1 go.

- Okay.
- Okay.

- So the only way we're
going to be able to do this
is if we divide and conquer.
So I'm conducting in the kitchen today,
which is a treat for everyone.
Mike is on a starter.
- Mmmm.
I shall be doing main course.
And Barry is on dessert.
- I hate being in this position
cause I'm the nearest to the judges

and they properly look at
everything you're doing.
So yes, I'm in charge of the starter.

I'm making a galette pancake
filled with French sausage,
French pork belly, garlic, onions.

It's basically a big,
thick, savoury pancake
stuffed with delicious ingredients.
- Okay.
- Okay.
- So I've started with a pancake batter,

which is a mix of buckwheat
flour and plain flour
to give the pancakes more of a texture.
They're going to be kind of a thickness

of like an American pancake,
but just a lot bigger.

And when we chuck all this
stuff in and all the filling,
you're going to be left with thick wedges,
with some lovely pickled salad and a mayo
to kind of offset the meaty indulgence.
- The crepes that we had
used interesting ingredients
and kind of like levelled them up

by taking inspiration from
other parts of the world.
I was like, "We could do that."

And then, in a lot of the
brasseries that we went to,
we had charcuterie boards for starters.

And I thought, what if we
could combine the crepe
with charcuterie, and gribiche,
which was something we had... and that I had absolutely no idea
was a real thing.
Ben cooked it for us a few months ago.
- [Mike] Yeah, in a fish and chip battle.
- And we were like, you've made this up.

And then the first day
that we were in Paris,

Alex, French Guy Cooking,
took us to a sandwich place,
and in one of the sandwiches
was this magical thing called gribiche.

And I was like, that's going
to go fantastically well

with the charcuterie,
and with the pancakes,
it'll be perfect.

- They make sandwiches, but
they do it in a modern way.

They would use old fashioned
French food, but you know,
change the shape and make it a sandwich.

We've got some Morteau
with gribiche sauce.

Morteau is like some
sort of a smoked sausage
but it's very bold in terms of flavour.
Veal's tongue, a classic.
And then you've got haddock with cream,
and Prince de Paris with a butter.

- Cheers.
- Go for it.

They are just consistently
the best sandwiches
I've ever eaten in Paris.
- So all this year,

our normals are competing
against each other to win badges,
to show improvement.
And today there is a French cuisine badge
up for grabs for all, or none of them.

If you think they have
respected the ingredients

and presented something
that is representative
and celebratory of French produce
and the influences from the trip.
- And for our main course.
- Roscoff onion, Limousin apple,
tarte tatin served with puy lentils,
a quick paté and a slaw.

Now we were given Roscoff onions
during a tasting challenge,
but also when we went to Rungis,

just saw the literally
miles of fresh produce

that was there and what
better way to cook them
than in Armagnac.
So I've got Roscoff onions,
the Limousin apples into a pan.
Butter, Armagnac, tarragon, thyme,
sugar, red wine vinegar, anchovies.
Cook all of that down.

And that's going to go
into little tart cases,
we're going to do individual ones.
Simple dishes done elegantly.

- The golden apple it's
actually the apple to use
for the apple tarte tatin,
because it's one of the softest one,
so when you cook it through
and you can turn it round very nicely.

So in the choice of
ingredient, absolutely spot on.
So now it's the balance we're looking at.
- I am making a wine poached fruit trifle.

- [Franck] (speaking
French) "Very good, English and French together".
- Yes, exactly.

Trifle is one of things
I, growing up, loved,

but at the same time, I
wanted to celebrate wine
and this delicious produce.
And then at the bottom,
a beautiful enriched brioche dough,

which I'm making now, it's
got mixed spices in it
and a tonne of beautiful French butter.
I bring it together in a mixer,

working it hard and then
resting it for 45 minutes.

And then it's time to
move on to my creme pat.
I've got my milk and vanilla mixture,

I mixed with my eggy mixture
and then to finish it off,
once it's all thickened up,

I'm adding in my praline... erm,
homemade by the chef team.
And it is exquisite.

- [Ben] He's stealing
your moment with flambé.

- [Jamie] It's just on fire.
- Don't steal my-
- I'm just saying-
Oh, that's still on fire.
- That's French, isn't it?
- [Jamie] What, flambé?
- [Ben] Flambé, sauté.

- This is the base to my
amazing filling for my galletes.
So we've got spring onions, garlic,
fennel, and mustard seeds.
Now I've got hispi cabbage going in.
I'm going to pop a lid on

and basically steam that
through for a couple of minutes.

Then add my radishes,
season with salt and pepper
wait for it to cool,

and then I'm stirring this
whole mixture through my batter
- Oh, is that a metal whisk on my pans?
- Chef?
Chef, I know how important creme pat is

to a French chef.
- Get out of my way.
- Is this okay?
Cause I'm nervous.
It's like, it was getting a bit lumpy.
- No, I think it's okay.
I never seen anything like it in my life,
but I think it's something.
(everyone laughs)

- Time-wise, you've had
25% of your time already.
Does that bother you?
- [Jamie] No idea.
- How do these three dishes go together?
Like, what's your vision?

- My concept is to take
the best of French produce
and some traditional style French dishes,

but give them a little twist.
- Okay.

- Cause what we learned
was that you can get
all of the best ingredients,

you can have all of the best
stuff there ready to go,
but then you don't have to pay attention
to all of the rules from the past

take it in any direction
that you want to go.

- The winery was probably
the best example of that.

Pick up amazing French grapes
from around different regions
and celebrate those,
but then be prepared to break the rules
in the combination of blending.
So put different grapes with other grapes

that wouldn't necessarily
traditionally be a thing,
but if it makes great wine, why not?
- So I'm using this praline,

which the food team
have knocked up for us.
It's full of beautiful French hazelnuts.

So I'm putting four tablespoons
of this into my creme pat,
(everyone shouting and mumbling)

which'll transform it
into something "belle".
That's the one, "belle".

- [Jamie] Need to have to
make my- (upbeat music)

- Tarte tatin's going into
the oven, 20 to 25 minutes,
so the pastry rises up lovely and golden.
Let's talk about puy lentils.

- Puy.
- Puy.

Puy lentils, more Roscoff
onion, garlic, anchovies, thyme,

tarragon, chicken stock, red
wine, all gonna boil away,
simmer down.
They're going to be delicious.

Similar flavour profile
to the tarte tatin,

but obviously with a
very different texture.
- I am going to make a mayonnaise.

I'm going to use this
wonderful French mustard,
from Beaune.
- So be careful, because with that,
it's not made with vinegar.
So it's still a strong mustard,

but it's not as acidic
as the Dijon mustard.

- And the reason for that
is because I'm adding to it
capers and cornichons.
So that's going to add more acidity,
more pickled-ness to the mayo.
I've got a whole egg and an egg yolk.

- Oh my God, that's
not a mayonnaise is it?

But call it, why you don't
call it "Mike sauce?"

- Barry, can we swap?
- [Barry] Excuse me chef.
- Can I do this over here?
And you come back over here?
- What, to make Mike-onnaise?
- Yeah, I'd like to-
- [Ben] Mike-onnaise (laughs).

(Franck laughs)
- I really want to see,
I want to learn something.
I've never made Mike-onnaise before.
(everyone laughs)
So garlic, lemon zest?

- Garlic, lemon zest,
juice, Burgundy mustard,
capers, and cornichons, eggs and then oil.

- He's in that position
right next to the chefs
because I gave him the easiest dish.
- Oh, okay.
- So there shouldn't be any issues.
- [Barry] How kind of you.
What a good person you are.
- [Jamie] I know.

- It's nice to celebrate
the shape of fruit,
not just dice anything.
The fig's still got a fig shape.
The pear have still got the shape of pear.
- I agree.
- We were very lucky,

we had a fantastic meal
in Paris by Alex Marchon,
and it was kind of veg-forward,
it was a little bit of fish involved,
but it was very much seasonal veg.
And every plate just celebrated what,
basically he picked up from Rungis market,
from him and his team that very day.
And it was just a real celebration
of how simple food can be.

But again, with influences
from all over the world.
A Japanese plate, but with French produce
that just sang to us.
A bold statement,

but one of my favourite
plates of food this year

was his carpaccio of turnip
with a walnut praline,
a herb oil, confit lemon.
It was just incredible.

Flavour profile that I'd
never even considered.
And it, yeah, mind-blowing.
- Interesting,

that's something I might
do myself actually.
So, tell us, what are you doing?
- Now I'm creating my poaching liquid.
I've got my beautiful red wine
and I'm turning into a...
Is it a mulled wine?

I've got some sugar,
spices and orange in there,
poaching my fruits in that.
I'm taking the fruits out and using that
to kind of build the trifle

and then reduce this sauce
to coat it over the top.
- Isn't it convenient how Baz's recipe
is already pear shaped?
(Jamie laughs)
So pickled cucumber,
I've ribboned a cucumber,
put it in a bowl with a pinch of salt,
draws out all the moisture,
gonna leave that.

In the meantime, I'm boiling
up my pickling liquid,
which is like sugar, water, vinegar,
and fennel and mustard seeds.
- You've had half your time, just over.
(intense music)

- Starting my paté... shallot,
garlic, chicken livers,
(Jamie coughs)
a berbere spice mix which is punchy,
thyme, all going in, frying off.
Then we go in with some more Armagnac,
some more fire for fun.
- Oh, goodness.
More flambé?

- And we'll blend it up with
double cream and butter.
(intense music)

- I mean, when you look
at the amount of butter
he puts into that.
It's not really...
We don't call this a paté,
to be honest with you.
In France, we call this a parfait.
- We went to a city Fromagerie,

where they brought organic,
unpasteurized goat's milk

into the city and she made
her own cheeses on site,

just like a mixture between
7, 8, 9, 10 day press.

But then she would either
roll them or infuse them

with some really unusual
flavours like Sakura,
like the Japanese cherry blossom leaf

and did it with like Mojito,
so like dried mint and lime,

and some really unusual,
kind of push the boat out,
traditional French cheese making.
But then just with a twist.

- Now my brioche has
rested for 45 minutes,
in the oven for 20.
- Coming up to the last 45 minutes,

and then we're going to
want you to plate one plate

of each course with the wine
that you're pairing with it.

- Again, I'm making a
dressing for my salad.

- Okay.
- A Mike dressing.
Basically got a repeat of the ingredients
that I've been using throughout.

So we've got the mustard,
we've got some cider vinegar,

black pepper, so I'm just
going to mix that altogether

and create a little dressing
to go over my salad.

- [Franck] So basically
it's a French dressing.
- [Mike] Is it a French dressing?

- It could be a French
dressing, absolutely.

You know, so we'll call
it French dressing.

- French dre-
Brilliant.
- You just do an emulsion, basically.
- [Ben] You've got 32 minutes left.
- The final element of my dish is my slaw.
So, I'm just making some baton.

- [Franck] Yeah, or julienne,
you can call julienne.
- [Jamie] Julienne, julienne.
- [Franck] Julienne is a nice term to use.
- Julienne of Limousin apple.

And I'm going to mix
that with some tarragon,

some olive oil, pomegranate
molasses and some lemon juice.

- [Ben] They don't sound
very French ingredients.
- They're not very French,
but they're more Moroccan.

And obviously Morocco has
a massive French influence

within it, so I thought, why
not combine them together?
- You're right.
- Break the rules.
(intense music)
- Sausage time and pork belly time.
So I've got a pan preheated.

I'm now laying my sausage and
my pork belly on the bottom

to create a base, gonna
brown it off really nicely.

Then add the pancake batter on
top of that and cook it out.
- [Ben] 30 Minutes remaining.
- Just making my jelly.

Turning my boiling hot
liquid into nice, cool jelly.

- Was it boiling liquid,
or was it poaching liquid?
- It was poaching, perfectly poaching.
(everyone laughs)

- And do you know what? We've
also got three delicious wines
to pair with these three courses
all from the same Domaine in Burgundy.

Now, J, we had a master
class from a sommelier
on a rooftop in Paris,

which was rather special.
What did you learn from that,
that you're bringing to today?
- Part of what we learned is that
wine is such a personal preference

and what tastes good to
me is absolutely fine.

But the biggest thing I
learned from that sommelier

was that the best bottle
of wine is an empty one

because it means that
somebody has enjoyed it.

- Ebbers has a lot of
good wine at his house.
(everyone laughs)

- I tell you what, the glass
recycling day at my place...
(everyone continues laughing)
- We've got a white,

it's a Chardonnay that's
going to pair beautifully
with Mike's because of the citrus,
the green fruit that's within that.

Great, we've then got
two reds to choose from.
Now, one is more aged.
It's a bit more oaky.

That's going to go
really nicely with mine.
Whereas Barry's one,

a few more hints of vanilla
coming through in that.
Think that's going to be slightly sweeter
to go with Barry's sweet dish.
- All right guys, you made it tasty,
now you're going to make it beautiful.

(bell dings)
You've got 20 minutes left.
- [Barry] Okay.
(intense music)
Oh goodness.
Right, the pressure's now building now,
because time is against me.
I've got my brioche on the bottom

and then I've got my poached
fruit for the next layer.
I want to squish it down,

clean the glass, into the
freezer for a few minutes
and then onto my next layer,
which will be my creme pat,
then my jelly, and then my cream.
(intense music)
- Last 10 minutes.
(intense music continues)
- I have to be brave, turn it over.

Take the loose bottom off
and then get it on the plate.

whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa.
- 90 seconds.

Barry!

There's always one.

- So first course,
starter, please, dig in.

It's appetising.

- Seasoning good, balance good.
Thickness of the pancake,

but in terms of flavour,
I think you've done a good job.
I think you've done a very good job,

to drink with it and see if that works.
I guess that's the whole point of it.
The wine pairs very well with it.
It really cut it through.
It works well.
It works well, well done.
It's a good pairing.

- It's definitely on the,

the fresh fruit, which with

they're kind of helping each other out.

They balance each other

- Thank you.

Your turn.
- Yup.

and I thought it's a shame to cut into it.
- We're all going "Oh good, good."

Franck is silent.

- Silence is everything.
- I think it looks good.
I don't think it looks beautiful.
- Okay.
- We all have this thing in us.
We can cook simple.
But when you start to plate it up,
we try to do too much.

- Straight off, I'll
tell you what I think,
I think it's a delicious main course

and it's nice that it is
kind of seasonal veg forward.
Yeah, there's a little bit of parfait
with the chicken livers,

but the rest is brilliant and

And some wonderful
flavours with Premier cru.
I like it.
- [Barry] Poised.

- Well, I think it's
almost perfect for me.

You know, I think the food
pairing is actually very nice.
It goes very well with the wine.
The acidity and the sweetness of the paté
and the rest goes very well.

You've done very well with

which I was a bit concerned of

because I thought it will
be too sweet, but it's not.
The only little critical,
because just to help you out,

I will be happy with it,

the only thing I would

it's this little apple here,

I find them a little too
acidic to go with the rest.
But that's the only thing, it's tiny.
- And delicious wine to go with it.
You've got two ticks.
- Two ticks.
- No pressure on the dessert Baz.

- I do like the presentation,
I think is very nice.

I like the way, actually,
you put it in a glass
because in France we call it Verrine,

so it's very French as well
to have food in a glass.

And the layers are probably
done very well as well.

You know, it's not one
more than the others.

So I'm looking forward
to dig the spoon into it.
I like it, but-
- It's very rich.

You need to get through to
the fruit, to balance it.

- How many gelatin leaves
did you put in your jelly?
- Six.

- I can feel it.
- [Barry] Can you?
(everyone laughs)
- I reckon if you take this disc alone
and you chuck it on the floor it might bounce.
(everyone laughs)

- Were you scared about
it setting in time?
That feels like it was a quick set.
A little bit of spicing, the mulled spice.

It's not as much as I
thought it was going to be.
The hazelnut is the strongest in that.
- For me, the texture is here.
The taste is here, it's a bit too sweet.
If I had this-
In fact, actually,

it's so sweet and it's
not to disregard to you.

It's so sweet that one spoon
it's plenty enough for me
because I can't eat the rest.

However, your ingredient are
very nicely put together.
I like the grapes.

I like the way you blend
things all together.

I'm not sure of the
jelly, it was a bit of a joke,
it's a bit too overset,
but why not putting a coulis?

You know, a coulis would
have been nice as well
or slightly set coulis.

And it would have worked
perfectly as well,

but definitely not the
Ferrero Rocher on top,
once you ate that, the Ferrero Rocher,
plus the praline, plus the sweet jelly,

I think I'm going to have my
eyes open (everyone laughs)

for the next eight hours.
I need to sleep, you know.

- Don't forget, it's paired
perfectly with the wine.

So please, that might
pull it back a little bit.

- Do you know what, you're saved
by the acidity of the wine,
because I don't think I would typically

put such a sort of a high
acid, fruit forward wine
with dessert.
But, thank goodness cause it kind of cuts.
I think the hazelnut praline creme pat
is the best part of that.
It's my absolute favourite.
- The pears are absolutely gorgeous.

But I think there's a
lot on top of the pears
before you reach them.

Overall, I think you've done
a very good job, you three.
I think it's fantastic.

I think you've done a
very, very, very good job.
Well thought as well, well put together.

The wine works very well with
it as well, so excellent.

- I think that really
does actually mean a lot.
And I can't remember the last time
we've had such great positive criticism,
like constructive criticism.
So it's really valuable,

especially on the journey
that we're on at the moment
to hear honesty like that,

because it will help
us be better in future.
- However, it is a competition.
So, if we draw a line in the sand
with French cuisine badge in mind.
Do you think you are able to award one,
two or three badges today?

- I can definitely give one
without a shadow of a doubt.
And we knew who it would be.

I think we get the badge
with keep learning,
and a badge with pat on the back.
- You get a badge and a pat on the back.
- Lucky, you lucky-
- Nicely done.
- I'm very happy about that.

However, I kind of feel like
I might have let you down
a little bit.
(everyone laughs)

- It's as if the guy
who did all the research
did really well.

Well, I'm going to call it,
two badges out of three.
That's enough for a pass on the challenge.

to the French Ministry

I can't wait to go back already.

you might learn something.
